quiz.title: Mixed Factoring Strategies
quiz.subtitle: Unit 11 Quiz 7: Choosing and Combining Methods
quiz.subject: Mathematics

questions.question: Factor completely: $3x^2 - 30x + 75$
questions.explanation: First, factor out the GCF: $3(x^2 - 10x + 25)$. Then recognize the perfect square trinomial inside the parentheses: $3(x - 5)^2$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $2x^3 + 4x^2 - 30x$
questions.explanation: Factor out the GCF $2x$ first: $2x(x^2 + 2x - 15)$. Then factor the simple trinomial: $2x(x + 5)(x - 3)$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $ax + ay - bx - by$
questions.explanation: Use the grouping method: $a(x + y) - b(x + y)$. Factor out the common binomial $(x + y)$ to get $(a - b)(x + y)$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $5x^2 - 80$
questions.explanation: Factor out the GCF: $5(x^2 - 16)$. Then factor the difference of squares: $5(x - 4)(x + 4)$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $x^3 - x^2 - 4x + 4$
questions.explanation: Group terms: $x^2(x - 1) - 4(x - 1)$. This gives $(x^2 - 4)(x - 1)$. Factor the difference of squares: $(x - 2)(x + 2)(x - 1)$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $2x^2 + 11x + 5$
questions.explanation: Use the AC method ($AC=10, B=11$). Split the middle term: $2x^2 + 10x + x + 5$. Group: $2x(x + 5) + 1(x + 5)$. Result: $(2x + 1)(x + 5)$.

questions.question: What is the first step when factoring any polynomial expression?
options: Factor out the Greatest Common Factor (GCF)
Check if it is a difference of squares
questions.explanation: The primary rule of factoring is to always look for and factor out the GCF before applying other methods.

questions.question: Factor completely: $-x^2 + 5x + 6$
questions.explanation: First factor out -1: $-(x^2 - 5x - 6)$. Then factor the trinomial: $-(x - 6)(x + 1)$.

questions.question: Factor completely: $x^4 - 81y^4$
questions.explanation: First, factor as a difference of squares: $(x^2 - 9y^2)(x^2 + 9y^2)$. The first factor is another difference of squares, yielding $(x - 3y)(x + 3y)(x^2 + 9y^2)$.

scoreMessages.90: Brilliant! You've mastered the art of choosing the right factoring strategy.
scoreMessages.70: Good work. Keep an eye out for GCFs and multi-step problems.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Always check if your remaining factors can be factored further.
scoreMessages.0: Remember the sequence: 1. GCF, 2. Count terms (2 terms=square? 3 terms=trinomial? 4 terms=grouping?).
